description: Bundle of six family/party card games. Each deck has about a hundred cards. Included are "Battle of the Ages" (Kids v Grown-ups trivia, "The Big Quiz" (Basic trivia), "Charades", "Mimic the Music" (a capella humming Name That Tune), "Impossible Decisions" (Would you rather do/have this or that? - both suck), "Who Am I?" (Think Inglorious Basterds bar scene). Included are minute timer, headbands for "Who Am I?" and rule sheet for all six games.

After the last Dark Moon, the Demon King, Blasphemy, broke in the Kingdom of Arcadia and stole the 4 Elemental Stones of our world. With that much power, it is inevitable that he will destroy the mighty Kingdom and undoubtedly everyone in it. The King is looking for brave leaders to recruit heroes, gain power within the guilds, and race through the dungeon to destroy Blasphemy. Will you adventure through the realms?

Adventure Realms is a worker placement and deck building game in which you will recruit new heroes, gain power within the guilds, and race through the dungeon. Gain powerful elemental stones to enhance certain items and heroes and gain extra end game victory points. You can also complete quests by meeting certain requirements. Stuck in lower levels of the dungeon? No worries, just play some devastating magic cards to gain the lead in the dungeon.

Adventure Realms is completely done in beautiful 16-bit graphics by FinalBossBlues and graphically designed by Pete Jank. It is reminiscent to the old school Super Nintendo games such as Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest.

On a player's turn, they will play 1 of their hero cards and place an agent into an Agent Space. These spaces will gain you specific rewards. On top of that, the hero card you played will also give you specific resources or abilities for that turn.

The objective of Adventure Realms is to gain Journey Flags to race through the dungeon. Once everyone has passed on their turns, players will enter the dungeon phase in which magic cards can be played to boost your levels in the dungeon. The player who had traveled through the dungeon the furthest will gain the first player rewards. The game will continue like this until a player has gained 10 victory points or until the dungeon deck has run out.

If you like to have fun with card games, as easy to learn as UNO, you will love this game, it is very easy and fun.

Each player starts with 5 lives (sets). Every turn, the player has to put a card on the center trying not to pass 21. Players count the numbers on their cards and, if they are more than 21, you lose one of your 5 sets.  If a player loses all 5 sets (lives), they are eliminated from the game.  The winner is the last player in the game.

Cards have a Tennis theme.

Battle Havoc! is easy to learn and play fantasy wargame where each player commands an army and lead it to the victory on the battlefields. Thanks to alternative activation, all players are involved continuously in action.

Each unit represents up to a few hundreds of men and the game doesn’t have any particular scale, as players can choose to play with either 28mm or 10mm miniatures.

Fight big battles with just a handful miniatures!

—description from the publisher

Unsere Wehrmacht im Manover Rot Gegen Blau ("Our Army in Maneuver, Red vs. Blue") is a tiddlywinks type board game about the First World War.
On the box cover (artist Hans Friedmann, Munchen) - army cavalry men and horses are galloping from right rear to left front, while infantry marches at upper left below trees.
The trifold game board depicts a military scene with blue forces on the left fighting gray forces on the right. A footbridge is shown at center near the top. At center is a sturdy bridge with a tank on its way to cross it. Below that, troops are crossing the river in a raft. Near bottom, troops are building a wooden bridge across the river.

It is a competitive game involving to teams (players) in red and blue color. Player are fighting on the game board with different type of measures: horses, tanks, aircrafts, cannons etc. Players, who lose all measures lose the game.

—user summary

"Who wants a cup of tea?" one of your friends calls out at a gaming event. This is the starting point of the game, now you need to find out who will be getting up to make it.

Next question "Who's in for the tea game?" once the player count is confirmed take two D6, pass them to the starting player (the one who asked for tea) who then rolls the dice.

To stay in the game the starting player has to roll less than '12' on two D6, if successful the dice are passed clockwise to the next player who is then required to roll less than '11' on two D6. The play rotates round the group of players with the number to roll under dropping by '1' each time until someone rolls that number or greater on the dice.

That player is declared the winner of the tea game, given a rousing cheer and sent off to make the tea for all of the other players. Huzzah!

The Bell of Treason is a fast-paced, card-driven board game in which two players experience the existential crisis faced by Czechoslovakia in response to Hitler’s territorial demands.

One player represents the ideal of trying to Defend the country, even without allies and at any cost. The other player represents the historically victorious ideal of agreeing to Concede the Sudetenland territory, in order to prevent bloodshed and hoping that Hitler’s demands would stop there.

The game adapts the crisis modeling system originally introduced in Fort Sumter and then further developed in Red Flag Over Paris. The game does not make any judgment about whether it would have been the right choice for Czechoslovakia to defend itself in 1938, nor whether such a defense could, in any sense, have been successful. Instead, it allows you to experience for yourself this crisis period of 1938, which forever influenced Czechoslovakia's path and the eventual course of World War II. The game can also be played solo, using an adaption of the system designed for Red Flag Over Paris.

—description from the publisher

Muffin Time is a chaotic card game with more twists and turns than you can shake a spork at! Battle your friends, family, and hyper-intelligent pets by drawing and playing from a deck of unique cards that'll either help you, thwart others, or mix things up for the sheer hell of it! To win the game, you just need to start your turn with exactly 10 cards in your hand but if you think that'll be easy, you're wrong (wronger than a duck wearing shoes - and that's pretty damn wrong).

This follows the same rules as the regular Muffin Time game.  Players draw a card on their turn and can choose to "place" up to three trap cards out of their hand. As a second part of their turn they either pick up one card or play one action card, which are all unique and can have wide-ranging consequences on the other players or game as a whole

The game ends an a player wins when someone starts their turn holding exactly 10 cards.

This deluxe version includes cards from the Pie Flavour and Rainbow booster packs so contains 200 cards (the standard 120 plus 40 from each booster).

Westward Rails is a stock-holding and route-building game about western expansion in the United States. Three-to-five players will bid on shares in five historical railroads, use that money to build routes, connect specific cities to satisfy demands, and develop important metropolitan areas, all with the aim of securing bigger and bigger dividends for the companies in which they are invested.

Westward Rails is played on a point-to-point map, sprawling out west by connecting cities to make major profit. On your turn, you choose to build, auction, or upgrade. This continues around the table until all demands have been met or companies run out of track. Most money wins the game.

ã‚«ã‚¨ãƒ«ã®è²¡å® (Kaeru no Zaihou) can be translated to “Frog Treasure”.

A band of frogs have been sent by the Frog King to retrieve treasure sleeping within a pond to the east of the Frog Kingdom. The frogs who bring back the greatest riches will receive high praise from the King.

In this game, players move pairs of frogs around a pond to collect treasure. Treasure of varying value is hidden beneath lily pad tiles. In order to collect the treasure, a player must sandwich the lily pad tile with two of his or her frogs or stack two frogs on top of the lily pad tile.

After collecting the treasure, players should decide whether they wish to display the treasure for game points or keep it in their hand for a power boost meaning greater mobility for their frogs and the ability to collect even more treasure.

Collecting certain combinations of treasure will also result in a higher number of points (for example: collecting gems of the same color).

There are a limited amount of times a player can take action so everyone must be careful to strategically plan their actions.

Your nerves are already frayed—it’s Valentine’s Day, and the pressure is on. Determined to make this day unforgettable, you’ve booked a table at the most exclusive restaurant in town, the perfect spot for a night of romance. But when you arrive, something’s not right. Your date is nowhere to be seen, the place is eerily empty, and the staff is missing. Just as panic starts to creep in, the door slams shut and locks behind you. What is happening? Romance takes a backseat as you scramble to unravel the mystery before the night goes from dreamy to downright disastrous!

The Cupid Crisis, title #4 in the Holiday Hijinks line, is an escape room-style game in just 18 cards! As a group, you will solve a series of puzzles to unravel a mystery.

Puzzles may test your perception, wordplay, and lateral thinking. English language fluency is required.

When you have solved a puzzle on the cards, you will enter the answer into the companion website (compatible with all smartphones and computers) and it will check whether you are correct. If you are, the website will tell you which card or cards to take next. The website also contains a graduated hint system, so if you get stuck you can get just a small hint about the current puzzle to get moving again without giving too much away.

This system is non-destructible: some groups may choose to write on cards, but this is not required. A group cannot re-play the game but can pass it on to another group for their use.

This entry in the series takes about an hour to solve and is rated 3 out of 3 in difficulty.

Dart Bros vs Zombos is a 1-4 player, cooperative darts game that puts you in the hero role. Be a Dart Bro (or Sis) and help save fleeing people from the Tinkerbrians and their horde of terrifying Zombos.

Each player chooses their own darts skill level (novice, expert, or pro).

     The horde is created out of the Zombo deck.
     The cards will tell you where your targets are
     Fire 3 darts each turn to eliminate the incoming Zombos
     Each round more Zombos appear and move closer towards you
     If bitten, lose a dart. Lose 3 darts, you are eliminated
     Use special item cards strategically to help ensure victory


To win, use your skill and strategy to make it past the Tinkerbrains and their Zombos while saving as many people as you can. Add up your points to see how well you did and who is the best Zombo slayer on your team!

—description from the designer

The Long Way Home is a hybrid Tabletop RPG supplement for use with the Deep Space D-6 board game. The story begins with your ship stranded in unknown space in the aftermath of an ambush. With limited fuel and a failing warp drive, you'll travel through the galaxy, explore strange new worlds, make difficult choices, and ultimately find your way home to the United Earths headquarters. A player sheet tracks your progress, provides ship upgrades, and outlines the traits of your unique crew.

Each turn, you'll decide where to travel, spending precious fuel to get there. Events and encounters outline the stipulations of combat. Occasionally, you'll have to make a choice. These choices can be modified by your crew, skill checks, and previously made choices. Can you unravel the mysteries of them galaxies and get your crew back home safe?

Horizon 1 is a solitaire science fiction settlement-building game of strategy, resource management, and above all, growth and survival.

This game is an entry in the 2021 Solitaire Print and Play Contest.

Overview:

Priority 1: Establish and develop the Horizon 1 settlement on planet Cerberus.
Priority 2: Maximise settlement population.
Priority 3: Extract as many minerals as possible from the planet crust.

Your settlers make planetfall on Cerberus, 2.6 light years from Earth. As the Governor of the Horizon 1 settlement, your task is to ensure their safety, to build facilities in which they can live and work and, most importantly, to research and understand this strange new world.

Turn structure:

The game is played over a series of game turns. Each game turn consists of a number of phases, performed in the order below.

     Resource collection phase. Collect food and ore resources.
     Research phase. Check if scientific breakthroughs occur, and (optionally) change research focus or projects.
     Movement phase. Move units, explore terrain, prospect, and move aliens.
     Building phase (optional). Use Engineer (ENGINR) units to build / demolish modules.
     Combat phase. Any aliens present engage colonial militia in combat.
     Event phase. Draw and resolve an event card, and flip the Day / Night counter.
     Status check phase. Update position of status counters on the status board. Do an approval check.


The game ends immediately when any of the following conditions occur:

     The Life support module is destroyed.
     Settler rebellion occurs.
     There are no cards remaining in the draw pile of event cards.
     Settlement population (POP) reaches zero.


When the game ends, your Victory Points (VPs) total = population + ore mined. Some event and technology cards also provide VPs.

—description from the designer

Players learn StanisÅ‚aw Moniuszko's biography on the board while completing their own hidden goals pointed out on the goal cards. To complete these goals players should find a match between two opened biography cards. Everything happens simultaneosly so try to find match quicker than the opponents. The first player who'll "live" Moniuszko's life wins.

This game is inspired by the creators of "Snappy Dressers".

•••

Planszowa zabawa dla dzieci i dorosÅ‚ych.

Å»ycie i twórczoÅ›Ä‡ StanisÅ‚awa Moniuszki to bogaty materiaÅ‚ na niejednÄ… ksiÄ…Å¼kÄ™ czy film. A co dopiero przeÅ‚oÅ¼yÄ‡ to na jÄ™zyk gry. Autorowi tej, Karolowi Madajowi, udaÅ‚o siÄ™ poÅ‚Ä…czyÄ‡ element edukacyjny ze swoistym napiÄ™ciem, które towarzyszy kaÅ¼demu grajÄ…cemu – chÄ™Ä‡ wygranej. Frustracji nie przysparza nieznajomoÅ›Ä‡ faktów z Å¼ycia kompozytora. Gdzie podróÅ¼owaÅ‚, co i kiedy komponowaÅ‚, rytmikÄ™ jakich taÅ„ców narodowych wprowadzaÅ‚ do swoich utworów, gdzie mieszkaÅ‚ w Warszawie – tÄ™ czÄ™Å›Ä‡, pomocnÄ… w czasie gry opracowaÅ‚a dr Hanna Winiszewska. JeÅ›li chcesz wygraÄ‡, to przeczytanie tych informacji z instrukcji jest elementem obowiÄ…zkowym.

Gra wydana zostaÅ‚a z okazji Roku Moniuszki.

Iconoclash: LevelMAX is a stand-alone expansion and features 4 new, cross-over fighters for the Iconoclash system from Level 99 Games:


     Zsolt: This relentless hunter never ceases, releasing his flurry of attacks with his arsenal of weapons. There’s no escape!
     Khadath: The master of the portal takes to the battlefield and assumes control. By summoning his Gate Trap he can attack from any range.
     Deques: Is your deck ready and do you want to duel? After studying the meta game for years, Deques has readied his deck of trading cards for any situation. Summon all sorts of monsters to become the champion!
     Esfir: Bring down the house with this hothead who controls gravity. She sends her opponents flying into the stratosphere, creates blackholes, and inverts gravity with a snap of her fingers.


In LevelMAX you'll take the fight to the world of Seventh Cross with Mansion of Darkness and the Gilded Foyer maps.

Escape From Danger Dungeon, a co-operative board game based on the Tunnels and Trolls RPG system. Can your band overcome the foes and traps which block its way? Can your band discover an exit before being buried alive? Can your band avoid squabbling over the loot?  you can find out!

Your goal in Countaloupe is to rid yourself of slice cards as quickly as possible, and whoever clears their plate first wins.

Each player starts with slices numbered 1-16. On a turn, you roll 3-5 dice (depending on your current top slice) and the chance die. After your roll, if any single die or the sum of any number of dice matches your top slice, you remove it; keep removing slices as long as the numbers add up. If, for example, you rolled 1, 2, 5 at the start of the game, you could remove the 1, 2 & 3 slices.

You now either end your turn or roll again. If you roll again and fail to remove a slice, you must place slice cards back on your deck as a penalty.

The chance die may give you the opportunity to swap decks with another player — or force you to swap with whoever has the largest deck! Alternatively, you might gain the Nope! token and use it to block a deck, whether to keep an opponent from removing cards from it or to protect your deck from being stolen.

Countalope can also be played as a multi-round game, with players scoring 1 point per card removed, with a game ending when someone has 16 points. Whoever reaches 100 points first wins.

MASH has been brought back from the past and transformed into a hilariously fun, adult party game! A quick 10 to 20-minute game is perfect for anytime you want to play.

Thousands of different futures are possible since MASH includes 300 Fate Cards in 6 unique categories and 40 Scenario Cards, making the game endlessly playable!

Players lay down your picks under the MASH and the fortunista picks their favorite and you get points if yours is picked.  The player with the highest points wins the game.

Includes: 16 Mystery Dry Erase Fate Cards, 1 Mystery Dry Erase Scenario Card, 1 Spiral Dry Erase Card, 300 Fate Cards, 40 Scenario Cards, 1 MASH Banner Board, 4 Mash Tokens, 6 Dry Erase Markers

In Deluxe Domino Dice, each player in turn rolls up to seven domino-style dice — imagine two six-sided dice connected into a rectangular shape — and tries to place as many of them as possible following standard domino rules. The more dice you place, the more points you collect. You can re-roll once during your turn to try to place more dice, but if you can't place any, then you score nothing for that entire turn.

Travel back in time to the founding of one of the greatest cities of Mesoamerica and become a part of its history once again. Design the foundations of a great pre-Columbian civilization, with its buildings, temples, and a grand pyramid in the center. Find perfect locations for production buildings and great temples, and build the might of the great pyramid overlooking your city. Establish yourself as the very best among competing architects, and your project will secure you a spot among the great Founders of Teotihuacan!

Founders of Teotihuacan is a strategy game where you compete against your friends to create the best design of the city of Teotihuacan. Over the course of three to four rounds you will place your action disks to the main board, forming towers of varying strength, strategically use the bonuses they offer, and construct temples, resource buildings and the pyramid central to your project of Teotihuacan. You will balance generating resources and using them, as finding good locations on your city board becomes increasingly more difficult, and you will try to outwit your opponents, making use of an innovative and interactive action system. Finally, once the eclipse comes, all designs will be assessed and the player with the most points will win and become the architect to join the ranks of Founders of Teotihuacan!

Founders of Teotihuacan is a stand-alone game, related to Teotihuacan: City of Gods only by the shared setting of the ancient city of Teotihuacan. Thematically, the events in Founders takes place at an earlier time in history, while what was to become a magnificent city was yet in its infancy and only few inhabited the area.

On your turn, you must either perform an Action or pass. To perform an Action, place between 1 and 3 of your Action disks on an Action space on the Main board that already contains at least one disk (minimum a Bonus disk and possibly also opponent disk(s)), and carry out a corresponding Action. The Action disk(s) should be placed on top of the disk(s) already on that space, forming a stack. Each Action space can hold a maximum of 4 Action disks—including Bonus disks!

Your personal player board is divided into four Districts or quadrants. Buildings and Temples can only be placed within the two Districts closest to your Architect. Pyramid tiles can only be placed within the six Pyramid squares closest to your Architect. Your Action Strength is equal to the total number of disks (whether yours, an opponent’s disks, or Bonus disks) on an Action space.

After performing an Action (not when passing), move your Architect clockwise to the next side of your Player board, signifying
the end of your turn. This changes your Architect's Reach for your next turn. After all players have passed, the current round ends.

After the game has ended, players score additional Victory Points for how well their Districts complement their Pyramid.

—description from the publisher

Work hard, build a career, save in order to ensure a prosperous life for your family - this is the path that you have been recommended to follow. But if you stole a treasure, wouldn't the result be the same with much less effort? During your journey, you hear of dungeons, filled with treasures, guarded by golems who tirelessly patrol their dark corridors. How to miss such an opportunity? All you need are companions to act as a diversion while you collect the treasures and you will be "set for life"!

Each player chooses a unique character and use of cunning to pass under the nose of the guardian, embodied by OLEM. Take turns using your moves and actions to explore the dungeon and implement your strategy. But beware! If the Guardian hears you or spots your torchlight, he will tirelessly pursue you to try to imprison you!

Guardian and Thieves integrates the robot and board and takes advantage of the connection to the smartphone. Connect your phone to your speakers to fully enjoy the background music and let OLEM transport you, which reacts to your actions.

On their turn, a player moves his thief from 0 to 5 tiles and can perform 1 of several actions. But beware, some of these actions can aler t the golem to your presence!

The players win if they succeed to bring at least one treasure to the dungeon entrance.

A railway roll-and-write for 2 to 8 players

The six cities are in need of rail service, and it’s up to you to build the connections!

Roll the dice to find out what to build and where, take on contracts to connect cities, and build the longest connection you can.

Try and complete all your contracts before one player connects all six of their cities,and ends the game!

In Rolling Stock, up to 8 players compete to build the best railway networks.

Each round, the two custom railway dice are rolled.


    Choose a rail shape from one die, and draw it into a space of the terrain type from the other die.
    Or, use the numbers on the dice to take a contract to connect two cities.
    Add a station to connect multiple rail lines, or to fill in a tricky space.


Play continues until one player:


    connects all their cities together, or
    fails to make a move.


Then it’s one final round, and time for scoring!

—description from the publisher

A battle of wits for 2 players

You are a wizard, battling for dominance in the Duel Arena using your summoned Beasts. However, the magical abilities of your rival are the equal of your own — you will need to outwit your opponent in order to win. Gain control of eight Flames, and claim victory!

In Summoner Duel, two players compete to control the board. Each turn, both players choose two magic stones, and the combined result determines the current player’s movement options. Move one of your two Beasts around the board, and try to claim a space or defeat an opponent’s Beast.

You will have twelve turns to claim eight Flames, or eliminate your opponent!

—description from the publisher

A delivery race for 2 to 4 players
For the fastest deliveries in town, you can depend on the Witch Academy Courier Service!

As a junior witch, you are racing to complete your delivery route the fastest. You must fly to each town location in the correct order for your delivery route, The witch who completes their route and returns home first is the winner!

Slipstream Pocket is a card game that is played as a tabletop game.

Each player controls a witch, and is given a delivery route and five Flight cards to move them around the table. Six town locations are randomly placed in the centre, and you must place your Flight cards down in a pattern that moves your witch over each location in the correct order.

As you play your cards, your movement options become restricted, until you pick up cards from the tail of your slipstream. Plan your flight carefully!

If you can overlap your witch onto a slipstream in play, you can follow it for a speed boost and pick up your cards, gaining a big movement advantage!

Can you complete all your deliveries the fastest?

—description from the publisher

A flip-and-write game of inventory management for 1 to 8 players.

You have been summoned by the king for an important quest, but the road to the castle is long and dangerous — make sure you pack well!

In Inventory Quest, your task is to prepare a backpack full of supplies to help you on your journey to the castle.

Draw your chosen selection of items onto your dry erase player board, then draw 16 cards from the Journey deck to reveal the challenges you’ll face along the way. Erase your supplies as they are used up… will you survive to the end of the journey with the most gems to win?

There are six types of items you can add to your backpack:

    Food, consumed as you travel
    Rope, to cross various hazards
    Potions, for healing
    Swords and Bows, for fighting and hunting
    Shields, to protect against damage


The most important rule to remember when packing, is that you can only access items from the top of your bag. Pack your supplies poorly, and you might not be able to use items when you need them! If you get stuck, you can discard the blocking items; and if you’re lucky you might find a shop to buy replacements.

Try not to run out of food… you don’t want to starve before you reach your destination!

—description from the publisher

The Hungry Hungry Hippos Launchers game is a flippin' fast feeding frenzy as players launch plastic watermelons directly into their hippo's mouth. The motorized game unit has the hippos opening and closing their mouths while players continue to fling the melons, hoping to land the most shots. It's fun for kids to press and release the melons from the launcher, and watch each swallowed watermelon roll back down into the scorecard ramp. Like the classic Hungry Hungry Hippos game, this electronic game is fun for boys and girls ages 4 and up. Play it on rainy days, play dates, and Family Game Night.

ELECTRONIC FLIPPIN' FRENZY GAME: Introducing a twist on classic Hungry Hungry Hippos gameplay. In this electronic version of the board game, players race to launch plastic melons into their hippo's mouth
5 IN FOR THE WIN: Who likes watermelon? These hippos do! Each player gets 5 plastic watermelons. Ready, set, launch! The player whose hippo is the first to eat 5 melons wins
PRESS, SLIDE, RELEASE: Press down on the launching tab, slide your finger off the back, and it'll release the melon into the air. Try to get it to land right into your hippo's moving mouth
CHOMP CHOMP: The hippos' mouths open and close, adding an exciting challenge as kids try to get the watermelons into the hippos' mouths. It features Beginner and Expert modes of play
FUN FAMILY GAME: Remember playing the classic Hungry Hungry Hippos board game as a kid? This Hungry Hungry Hippos Launchers motorized game is great for kids' play dates, and rainy day entertainment

—description from the publisher

In Flip-Pix!. you start with a number of cards in hand, with one side of each card showing images and the other side showing letters.

Everyone plays at the same time. Pick up your cards, then play one of them image side up, then flip your cards over, find a card with the starting letter for that image, then play that card. Be creative to make matches! For an image of a unicorn, you could play a "U" to match "unicorn", an "A" to match "animal", or an "I" to match "imaginary creature". Flip your cards again to find an image that matches a played letter, and continue playing cards and flipping them.

Whoever first plays all of their cards wins!

It’s the most wonderful time of the year! Gather your friends and family together around the Christmas tree to collect beautiful ornaments, gifts, and stockings.

Cards are arranged in the center of the playing area forming a tree with presents placed below. Players will choose and place either a light or tinsel card onto the tree. Using the point total from all lights or tinsel cards on the tree (of the type just placed) will determine your selection value. That selection value is then used to pick an ornament hanging on the tree or select a present/stocking from beneath the tree. Ornaments and presents/stockings all score points in a variety of ways.

—description from the publisher

No Such Thing as a Free Sandwich is a mint tin party game for 2-8 players, ages 13+. Down to their last few slices of bread, players compete with one another in a variety of challenges to make the best (or worst) sandwiches according to a handful of different score categories such as "Taste", "Affordability", "Wow Factor", and more, using a hodgepodge of ingredients.

At the beginning of the game, each player draws 3 ingredient cards to add to their hand. Each ingredient card has different stat categories that affect how desirable an ingredient is for a given Challenge. At the beginning of each round, a Challenge card is drawn. The Challenge card outlines which stat categories each player’s sandwich should have. Players must play a minimum of 1 card for their sandwich. Cards must be played face-down. When all players are done creating their sandwich, the ingredients are revealed and the player with the sandwich best suited to the Challenge wins the round.

The player with the winning sandwich will keep the Challenge card for the round. Once all of the Challenge cards have been played, the player with the most Challenge cards collected wins the game.

—description from the designer

The Adventures of Dex Dixon the Board Game is a scenario-based strategy game set in a multi-spoked, inter-dimensional, noir, horror world filled with Paranormal Detectives, Monster Crime Bosses and Vampire Torch-Song Singers. Choose your Boss, recruit your Mugs, assemble your gear, and charge your magical powers. Defeat your opponents and obtain your objective by outwitting them with each characters’ unique abilities. No two game sessions will be the same.

A limited area skirmish game with characters that have specific powers and abilities that can be augmented with cards that you draw throughout the game.

—description from the designer

Kaboom! is a card game for 2 to 6 players. The objective is to collect points after each round.

At each turn a player, after receiving his cards, discards one, there are some special cards that allow you to roll the dice and change the color of the cards. Points are collected when the Kaboom card is discarded. The first option is a Double Kaboom, in which you have two Kaboom cards in hand, which you have either drawn from the draw pile, drawn from an opponent using the Woosh card or received during the deal. The second option is to discard a Kaboom card as your last car

The game ends when a player manages to score 10 points.

Get your fists in the air and go shopping! Check your shopping list and put the right items in your shopping basket, and be careful not to lose any unplanned items! At the same time, you should also play the virtue of being kind to others, if you find something that others need, you should be generous to give it back! Free parent-child handbook is included in the game!

Each player takes $10, a shopping basket, a shopping list and a price list.

Players take turns performing Buying items or turning over cards to earn money.

When a player buys all 7 items on the shopping list, the game is over and the player wins and becomes a little shopper!

In Ship Ahoy, a fast-paced children's game designed by acclaimed designer Fréderic Moyersoen, your goal is to sink the opponent’s ships by shooting at them with a special wooden cannon, while making sure your own ships stay afloat. You can play Ship Ahoy both on the sea of your table or on the vast ocean of your floor – the game itself has no borders! Additionally, the box contains 6 mini-expansions that will enrich the experience even more.

On their turn, Players chooses an opponent's boat and shoo the cannon to sink the ship. The game ends when a player loses all his/her boats. Players gets points for sinking boats. Whoever has the most points wins.

In Aerodome, players select a pilot to represent them in the Aerodome, craft their Maneuver Hands from their collection, and challenge others in a game of one-on-one aerial combat. During their turn, players activate cards to move their ship around the board, engage with special attacks against their foes, and hope that their pilot has a trick or two up their sleeve to become the champion of the Aerodome.
 Aerodome is a game of both chance and skill, expertly crafted as a quick to play, easy to learn, difficult to master gaming experience.

The Game

In each Aerodome game, rounds are broken up in three phases: Initiative, Action and End.

Initiative Phase
Each turn starts with the initiative phase. Players secretly select one of their 9 Battle cards from their hand and place it face down. Once both players are ready, they simultaneously reveal their selected cards. The player who revealed the highest initiative Battle card gets to complete their Action phase first.

Action Phase
During a player’s Action phase, they complete the actions listed on the active card’s action bar. Players must complete actions from the top of the card to the bottom, but can skip any action that is not locked.

Locked actions are indicated by the lock icon.

Reactive Actions with a black background allow players to perform the maneuver up to the speed listed.

Keywords and unique pilot abilities may also change how actions and cards interact. Once a player completes their Action phase, the turn proceeds to the next player.

End Phase
After both players have completed their Action phases, they return their active battle card to their hand and begin a new game turn. Cards with the Dazed keyword receive dazed tokens and cannot be returned to the player’s hand until they have played a card with the Recover keyword to remove dazed tokens.

When a fighter has taken 15 damage, they are defeated leaving the fighter remaining as the victor. Do you have what it takes to become the Aerodome Champion? Can you help decide the fate of the galactic-verse?

Whether you're a sheriff, a bandit or a brawler of the worst kind, in the Wild West you can only believe in two things: gunpowder and dynamite!
This explosive BANG! box includes 8 legendary expansions, for a disrupting gaming experience!
 What does this official BANG! collectors box contain?


     BANG! (base game)
     BANG! The Great Train Robbery – Expansion
     BANG! Dodge City – Expansion
     BANG! Gold Rush – Expansion
     BANG! Armed & Dangerous – Expansion (including Bloody Mary)
     BANG! Expansion Pack:
         BANG! Wild West Show – Expansion
         BANG! The Valley of Shadows – Expansion
         BANG! High Noon + A fistful of cards – Expansion
    
     The Stick of Dynamite – To be used in a game variant
     34 Wooden Bullets
     8 premium Dual Layer Boards
     Extra Content Slot
     Extra Cards: Annie Versary (from BANG! 10th Anniversary), Emiliano (from BANG! 20th Anniversary), and special characters and cards from BANG! The Bullet!: Uncle Will, Johnny Kisch, Claus "The Saint", "New Identity", and "Handcuffs"
     A single book for the rules (40 pages, 12.5×18 cm two-sided full-colour glossy stapled)



(please note there is also a product called "BANG! Dynamite Box: Storage Box and Accessories" which does NOT contain the games, but contains the premium Boards, the Wooden Bullets, and the Stick of Dynamite.)

—description from the publisher

The box, besides being filled with goodies, has a sleeve added that provides the coloured BANG! on its front and a description of the contents on its back.

All cards are 56×87 mm.

Fast-paced racing game! All players race at the same time to complete five unique Challenges. Players scramble to match their BLiTZ Row to their Challenge cards while preventing others to match theirs. Special "FLiP OUT" cards forces any player to swap out their current Challenge card and start over.

Each player starts with 5 challenge cards (top one face up), two round BLiTZ cards in their hand and four face up on the table. There are 2 draw piles and a discard area. Play begins when the dealer says "Blitz". The play action is DRAW, DISCARD, DOWN. Players (simultaneously, not taking turns) draw a round Blitz card, then discards (face up) a card that they don't need. This card becomes available for other players. Then places one down from their hand to fill in the row. When a player matches their BLiTZ row to their Challenge card, they yell "CHEDDAR" and all play pauses while they reset the board and turn over a new challenge card.
You can use any number of wild cards and can rearrange your row at any time. The winner is the one who completes all five Challenges and Shouts "CHEDDAR!"

Unique colorful round BLiTZ cards highlights the special Emoji on each card.

Let the Tournament begin! You and an opposing commander shall face off in a battle of wits for the prestigious title of Royal Commander!

In Champions!, two players will take turns upgrading and commanding legions of warriors to defeat their opponent in battle.

The game is played on an imagined 6 row by 3 column board, with either player picking one of the far back rows as their base row.

Each turn has two phases:
1. Movement: you will move your units around the board (rotate, move, fight). Cards move one space per turn.
2. Reinforce: you will summon a new scout or upgrade a scout to a champion (recruit, upgrade).

You win the battle, and the title of Royal General, if you move one of your units into your opponent’s base row.

In Aves (Spanish for “Birds”), players take on the roles of hungry birds. Seek out the best grubs to score points and gain special powers. Outwit your opponents and rule the skies!

The goal of Aves is to score the most points by eating grubs.
At the end of the game, the player with the highest score wins!

Players draw cards to move, eat grubs, collect bonus points, and affect others players moves.

The game ends the moment the Grubs deck runs out.

All players count up their points as well as bonus points from set bonuses or special rules. The player with the highest score wins! If there is a tie, the player who ate the most Grubs wins.

In the humorous and instructive card game Pandemic Poker, everyone wants to protect themselves from the infectious viruses. Mouth and nose protection or disinfectants will benefit you and a few rolls of toilet paper can also help you out.

It is important to keep your distance, also with regard to the playing cards: the cards have different values â€‹â€‹and may only be placed on the discard pile with a certain (number) distance. Each card has an additional function that can have an advantage or disadvantage for you or your fellow players. Whoever manages to discard all of his hand cards wins the game.

Pandemic Poker is Uno with distance rules and strange special abilities. No cards that are directly adjacent to it are placed on the stack, only those values â€‹â€‹may be placed that are indicated as permitted on the previous card. After all, we have to keep our distance. In addition, there are special cards that I can play at any time if I have two of the same type. So I suspend or draw cards. Alternatively, I also get rid of CoVid19 cards or swap cards in my hand. And speaking of CoVid19 cards. If we have three of them in hand, we are eliminated from the game. Whoever gets rid of all of his hand cards first wins.

Put down your flagons and strap on your swords, it’s time to delve through some dungeons in Tales from the Red Dragon Inn! A new 1-4 player cooperative board game by SlugFest Games!

In Tales you will take on the role of one of the famous characters from The Red Dragon Inn series of games as they tackle their day job of being big damn heroes. The multi-scenario campaign pits the players against game-controlled enemies tailor-made for each illustrated fold-out game map. Each scenario will take you to a new map, with new foes and even a few tricky puzzles to solve. You'll need to work together with the other players by equipping hero and item cards to support your allies who have their own unique abilities and roles.

Each scenario has specific objectives, so how you and your party beat each one varies from "kill all the enemies" to "survive X turns" to "protect this thing until something happens" to "get to this room on the map". All of the players win the scenario together by completing that scenario's final objective. They can also all lose together if any one of them are defeated in combat, or in the case of many scenarios, the enemies complete their own AI-controlled objective.

Race your opponents in this lightning fast, real time, set collection card game. Fight over limited ingredients in the Kitchen. Organize your cook space. Plan ahead by storing ingredients in your Pantry. Compete against other chefs to complete recipes as fast as you can and earn the prestigious Excellence Stars.

There are no turns. All players play at the same time.

Players attempt to complete Recipe cards as quickly as possible using Ingredients taken from the Kitchen. Each player has their own deck of recipes, but the ingredients in the Kitchen are shared. When players complete a Recipe, they set that recipe card along with any ingredients used to complete it aside in a completed pile. Players then reveal a new recipe from their deck.

When a player has no cards left to draw from their Recipe deck, the round ends. Players score one point for each completed Recipe and Ingredient used to complete those recipes (ignoring Sketchy Substitutes). The player with the most points, wins the round and earns a star card. Each star earned increases the difficulty for that player in future rounds by limiting the number of recipes they can have active. The first player to collect the required amount of stars, wins.

THE GAME ã‚ªãƒã‚±ã‚„ã—ãã®ã™ã†ã˜ã®ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒž is a new incarnation of The Game where players struggle to seal away ghosts and other creatures lurking about a haunted mansion.â€¨â€¨

The premise of the game is that players are naughty children who enter a haunted house and accidentally open a book that releases a host of demons. They must work to seal these escapees back into the book. However, the demons are actually Demons of Numbers and therefore the players cannot speak in numbers (or else be cursed and die).

The basic gameplay is the same as The Game, where players work together to discard all cards into four piles depending on the UP/DOWN conditions of each pile. During their turn, players discard either a larger or smaller value card(s) as appropriate. Afterwards, players refill their hand.â€¨â€¨

Players cannot share the numbers of the cards in their hand with other players but must find ways to collaborate in order to effectively place cards in the four piles so that all players can have zero cards in their hand at the end of the game.

If there is an exact difference of 10 between the card a player discards and the last card in a pile, the player is free to play the card regardless of the UP/DOWN direction of the pile.â€¨â€¨

In Demons of Numbers, there are also six types of effect cards (which are number cards with an effect written at the bottom): Reverse, Skip, Short, Draw 2, Silence, and Declaration of Death.

There are three types of ending results for the game: Total victory, victory, and loss.

--

Additional Information:

This all new game builds upon the original The Game with additional rules for a spookishly fresh gameplay experience.

Unlike The Game Extreme which added rules to make gameplay even more challenging for players, Demons of Numbers offers a more interactive, conversational experience. The new design also allows for up to 6 players.

Familiar “effects” are added to the game to give it a more UNO-esque familiarity. In fact, these changes have earned this version of the game the nickname “The Game Junior” by the original publisher.

The increased player number, new rules, and random events make it more difficult for players to find a repeatable pattern to beat the game and result in a making Demons of Numbers more of a “party game” for all ages and for gamers and non-gamers alike.

The designer, 326, felt that the original The Game had a title that was really not ideally optimized for easy internet searches, as well as artwork that would make it for children to convince their parents to purchase the game for them. He wanted to take a new approach and was able to find a willing partner in Arclight Games.

Illustrations are also by 326.

Titles is a movie-themed atmosphere and general culture game in which you will have to guess a movie title from a card.

At the start of the game, each player draws 5 cards and 1 other card is put in the center. On your turn, you had to choose between "play 1 of your cards then pick a new one" or "discard 1 to 5 cards and draw as much".

The game ends, when a player reaches 30 points. At the end of the game, we end the round so that everyone has played the same number of times, and the one with the most points wins the game.

In this scavenger hunt game, players flip over cards and rush to find items that match the description on the card. There are 3 ways to play, but whoever finds the specified number of items first is the winner.

Your day started off pretty well but by adding "shitty day" cards to your story, you find that it just gets more and more rotten.

Accumulate awkward and embarrassing situations to have the worst shitty day by picking or placing a card.
The winner is the player with the high score (points are written on each card). 
An aperitif game to spend hilarious evenings with friends.

Can you ensure a garam (hot) cup of chai (tea) is served to your ever-growing customers on a rainy day? Get ready to dive deep into running a chai tapri (tea shop) by ensuring that your customers get their specific chai and snack orders on time. Earn their appreciation for every correct order, but be quick as another player might steal a few of them away. Run the most successful shop, and be the wealthiest player at the end of the game!

Each turn in Chai Garam, players take one mandatory action, either selecting up to three ingredients from the display (tea leaves, additives, water, milk, godown power cards, etc.) or serving their cooked tea to the grid of customers in the central board and collecting money.

Additionally as free actions, players need to cook tea, compete for goals to improve their star ratings, attract customers to their own shops, or play a "Chai Garam" card to take a double action! The game continues until a special "evening" customer triggers the end of play or any player achieves five stars. At that point, whoever has the highest value from money as well as stars wins.
